text: A beat-up Chevy pulls into the all-night store's empty pa lot.
I tried to stand up and fly straight,  but it wasn't easy with that sumbitch  Reagan in the White House... Hi is getting out of the Chevy in a Hawaiian shirt, holdi a pump-action shotgun.
...I dunno, they say he's a decent  man, so... He primes the shotgun - WHOOSH - CLACK - and heads for th store.
...maybe his advisers are confused.
Full-face exposure of Hi once again in front of the mug-s wall.
Turn to the right! Hi obliges but shoots sympathetic glances at Ed who is  obviously upset, wiping away tears and snuffling behind t camera.
What's the matter, Ed?
My fai-ants left me.
She said her fiancee had run off  with a student cosmetologist who  knew how to ply her feminine wiles.
On Hi's profile. He turns back to Ed.
That sumbitch.
Don't forget his phone call, Ed!
You tell him I think he's a damn  fool, Ed. You tell him I said so -  H.I. McDunnough. And if he wants to  discuss it he knows where to find  me... As another police officer starts to lead him away:
...in the Maricopa County Maximum  Security Correctional Facility for  Men...
Looking up through her tears as Hi is led away.
...State Farm Road Number Thirty- one; Tempe, Arizona...
Struggling to call back over his shoulder as he is firmly led out the door.
...I'll be waiting! The door slams.
As Hi is once again escorted toward his cell. The Mopping Con is now in the middle-background, having w his way about halfway up the corridor since last time we him.
I can't say I was happy to be back  inside, but the flood of familiar  sights, sounds and faces almost made  it feel like a homecoming.
As Hi passes.
Grrrr...
Group is meeting again.
Most men your age, Hi, are getting  married and raising up a family.  They wouldn't accept prison as a  substitute. Hi looks sheepish.
...Would any of you men care to  comment? Two convicts sitting next to each other, GALE and EVELLE, appear to be friends.
But sometimes your career gotta come  before family.
Work is what's kept us happy.
Yeah, but Doc Schwartz is sayin' you  gotta accept responsibilities. I  mean I'm proud to say I got a  family... somewheres.

Looking down from the ceiling. In the foreground, lying o the top bunk, hands clasped behind his head as he stares into space is MOSES. Moses is a gnarled, elderly black co with wire-rimmed spectacles. On the lower bunk, also with hands clasped behind his head and staring off at the same spot in space, is Hi.
I tried to sort through what the Doc  had said, but prison ain't the easiest  place to think.
An' when they was no meat we ate  fowl. An' when they was no fowl we  ate crawdad. An' when they was no  crawdad to be foun', we ate San'.
You ate what?
(nodding)
We ate San'.
You ate sand?!
Dass right...
Hi faces the same three PAROLE OFFICERS across the same t
Well Boy, you done served your twenty  munce, and seeing as you never use  live ammo, we got no choice but to  return you to society.
These doors goan swing wide.
I didn't want to hurt anyone, Sir.
Hi, we respect that.
But you're just hurtin' yourself  with this rambunctious behavior.
I know that, sir.
Okay then.
Of a 7-Eleven parking lot, at night, deserted except for  Hi's car which sits untended, its engine rumbling.
Now I don't know how you come down  on the incarceration question... Hi backpedals into frame with a shotgun and a bag of cash
...whether it's for rehabilitation  or revenge. He spins and grabs his car-door handle. Locked. He tries back door. Locked.
...But I was beginning to think... As we hear the wail of an approaching siren, Hi takes it the heel and toe.
...that revenge is the only argument  makes any sense.
On Hi against the mug-shot wall.
Turn to the right!
Don't forget his latents, Ed!
We see his right hand being efficiently manipulated by Ed two hands: She is rolling each of his inked fingers into appropriate space on an exemplar sheet.
Hear about the paddy-wagon collided  with the segment mixer, Ed? Twelve  hardened criminals escaped. Ed's hand lingers on top of his.  Hi's other hand enters rest on top of hers.
Got a new beau?
No, Hi, I sure don't. Hi slips a ring off his own finger and slides it onto Ed'
Don't worry, I paid for it.
The surly Mopping Con has now worked his way up to the  foreground. Hi is being escorted past him to his cell.
They say that absence makes the heart  grow fonder, and for once they may  be right. Halfway up the corridor Hi points casually at the floor.
You missed a spot. The Mopping Con turns to watch him recede.
Grrrr...
Same high shot with Moses on the top bunk, Hi on the lowe
More and more my thoughts turned to  Ed, and I finally felt the pain of  imprisonment.
An' momma would frow the live crawdad  in a pot of boiln' water. Well one  day I decided to make my own  crawdad... We begin to crane down to tighten on the absently staring Hi.
...an' I frew it in a pot, forgettin'  to put in the water, ya see... Moses' voice is mixing down as we lose him from frame.
...and it was like I was makin'  popcorn, ya see... The joint is a  lonely place after lock-up and fights  out... We are now very close on Hi, staring.
...when the last of the cons has  been swept away by the sandman.
The underside of the top bunk. A sudden flash whitens and fades to leave the image of Ed smiling behind her camera, softly supered on the undersid of the bunk.
He wearily turns his head to profile on the pillow and sh his eyes.
But I couldn't help thinking that a  brighter future lay ahead - a future  that was only eight to fourteen months  away. Eyes closed, he is illuminated by a flash.
Hi and the same three officers.
Got a name for people like you, Hi.  That name is called recidivism.
Ree-peat O-fender.
Not a pretty name, is it, Hi?
No Sir, it sure ain't. That's one  bonehead name. But that ain't me  anymore.
You're not just tellin' us what we  wanna hear?
No Sir, no way.
'Cause we just wanna hear the truth.
Well then I guess I am tellin' you  what you wanna hear.
Boy, didn't we just tell you not to  do that?
Yessir.
Okay then.

Over Hi's shoulder as he strides toward a door marked  "Processing" and flings it open. It is the familiar booking room. Ed looks up from her cam having just snapped a picture of another suspect against hatched wall.
I'm walkin' in here on my knees, Ed -  a free man proposin'. Hi cocks a finger at the suspect.
Howdy Kurt.
As she nervously frets at her white bridal gown in front a mirror.
And so it was.
Don't forget the boo-kay, Ed!
Gazing earnestly into the camera. A congregation is seate behind her - the bride's side wearing police blues; the  groom's side, Hawaiian shirts.
I do.
Also staring into the camera.
You bet I do.
Over their shoulders, the minister.
Okay then.
On the newlyweds smiling at the camera.
On the newlyweds smiling at each other, profile to the ca
In the middle of a vast expanse of desert.
Ed's pa staked us to a starter home  in suburban Tempe...
Hi is working the drill press, wearing goggles and sweat- stained overalls.
...and I got a job drilling holes in  sheet metal. Next to him idly stands Bud, a veteran of the shop, with grimy face and a pair of goggles pushed up on his forehea
So we was doin' paramedical work in  affiliation with the state highway  system-not actually practicin',  y'understand - and me and Bill's  patrollin' down Nine Mile -
Bill Roberts?
(barking)
No, not that motherscratcher! Bill  Parker! Anyway, we're approachin'  the wreck, and there's a spherical  object arestin' on the highway... He pauses to blow and pop a bubble with his chewing gum.
...And it don't look like a piece a  the car.
Mostways the job was a lot like  prison, except Ed was waitin' at the  end of every day...
Hi is scowling at his paycheck. Behind the barred window fat cashier grins.
...and a paycheck at the end of every  week.
Gummint do take a bite, don't she?
Hi sits in a lawn chair in front of the trailer. Ed sits his lap, his arms around her. Both are wearing sunglasses looking at the setting sun. The scene is suffused with a  warm yellow light.
These were the happy days, the salad  days as they say... As the sun sets, the light is turning from yellow to ambe Hi and Ed watch, their heads following its slow downward  arc.

...and Ed felt that having a critter  was the next logical step. It was  all she thought about. The amber is turning to a more neutral dusky light as the sun has set. Hi and Ed continue to stare at the point whe it disappeared.
...Her point was that there was too  much love and beauty for just the  two of us... The dusk is slipping away into darkness.
...and every day we kept a child out  of the world was a day he might later  regret having missed. We are by now holding on pitch black. Crickets chirp. Fro the darkness:
That was beautiful.
Ed is crossing off the last day on the calendar before a circled in red.
So we worked at it on the days we  calculated most likely to be  fruitful...
Hi is wearily entering after a long day at work, clutchin his lunchpail.
...and we worked at it most other  days just to be sure. Ed flies into frame and leaps into his arms, covering him with kisses.
In each other's arms, Hi and Ed roll over on the bed.

Seemed like nothing could stand in  our way now... We pan with them rolling and continue off them to the nig table, on which sits a framed pair of photographs of Hi,  probably taken by Ed: One shows him full face, the other profile.
Ed sits in a lawn chair knitting a booty. Hi stands in Be shorts and an unbuttoned Hawaiian shirt, hosing down the  minuscule patch of front lawn.
...My lawless years were behind me;  our child rearin' years lay ahead.

head_text.subj: DUSTY ROAD LEADING UP TO TRAILER DAY

text: A squad car, its siren wailing, kicks up dust as it roars into the foreground.
Hi and Ed are seated on folding chairs facing an agent's  desk. Hi wears a sport coat over his Hawaiian shirt. Ed i in her dress blues.
It's true I've had a checkered past,  but Ed here is an officer of the law  twice decorated...
Looking, with a dead pan, from the file to Hi.
...So we figure it kind of evens  out. His face still deadly neutral, the agent looks back down the file and unfolds the accordioned rap sheet, revealing to be a couple feet long.
...But biology and the prejudices of  others conspired to keep us childless.
On Ed as she stares vacantly out the passenger window.
Our love for each other was stronger  than ever...
Driving. He looks from Ed out to the road.
...but I preminisced no return of  the salad days.
Over Hi's shoulder as he stares listlessly at himself in mirror, a razor held forgotten in one hand, his face half lathered and half shaved.
The pizazz had gone out of our lives.
The bedroom is somewhat messy. Ed sits on the edge of the bed, also staring listlessly. Her police uniform is on bu not yet buttoned. Her hands lie palm-up in her lap, like dead fish.
Ed lost all interest in both criminal  justice and housekeeping. Soon after,  she tendered her badge.
Once again Hi works as his sweaty gum-chewing colleague s idly by.
Even my job seemed as dry and bitter  as a hot prairie wind.
So here comes Bill a-walkin' down  Nine Mile - that's Bill Parker,  y'understand - got his sandwich in  one hand, the fuckin' head in the  other...
Alone in his Chevy. He looks to the side.
I even caught myself drivin' by  convenience stores...
7-Eleven.
...that weren't on the way home.
Hi and Ed sit listlessly watching TV.
Then one day the biggest news hit  the state since they built the Hoover  Dam... Ed perks up, reacting to something on TV. Hi notices her  reaction and also sloughs off his stupor to watch.
...The Arizona quints was born.
A newscaster silently reading copy. Behind him news foota of five nurses holding infants mortices in.
By "Arizona" quints I mean they was  born to a woman named Florence  Arizona.
Watching intently. Eyes still locked on the set, Ed reach her hand out to Hi. Eyes still locked on the set, Hi take her hand in his.
As you probably guessed, Florence  Arizona is the wife of Nathan Arizona.  And Nathan Arizona - well hell, you  know who he is...

head_text.subj: THE TV A LATE-NIGHT LOCAL COMMERCIAL

text: NATHAN ARIZONA, a stocky middle-aged man in a white polye suit, is gesturing expansively with his white cowboy hat  toward a one-story warehouse store with a football stadiu parking lot, chroma-keyed in behind him.
(mixing up on the TV)
So come on down to Unpainted Arizona  for the finest selection in fixtures  and appointments for your bathroom,  bedroom, beaudoir!
...The owner of the largest chain of  unpainted furniture and bathroom  fixture outlets throughout the  Southwest.
And if you can find lower prices  anywhere my name ain't Nathan Arizona!
As they slowly look from the TV set toward each other.
Hi lounges near one of the vending machines as a business puts in a quarter.

Yep, Florence had been taking  fertility pills, and she and Nathan  had hit the jackpot. The businessman takes his newspaper and releases the mach door as he turns to leave. Hi snags the door before it closes and takes his own five finger discount copy. He flips the paper over to look at the headline.
The banner headline of the Tempe Intelligencer is:
The subhead: "More Than We Can Handle,' Laughs Dad." Next it is a picture of Nathan.

Now y'all who're without sin can  cast the first stone... A pull back from the paper shows Hi and Ed reading it tog at home. They look from the paper to each other. Hi opens to an inside page and we pan a row of pictures - the five tots with their names underneath: "HARRY, BARRY, LARRY, GARRY and NATHAN JR."
...but we thought it was unfair that  some should have so many while others  should have so few.
In the middle of the desert. It reads: "WELCOME TO TEMPE!

We are floating in toward Ed who is seated, waiting, in t driver's seat of Hi's Chevy. Hi enters frame and cinches  down a ladder that is tied to the roof of the car. Pieces red flag flutter at either end of the ladder where it sti out beyond the car.
With the benefit of hindsight maybe  it wasn't such a hot idea... Hi gets in the car.
It starts down the long, winding road leading away from t trailer, kicking up dust.

...but at the time, Ed's little plan  seemed like the solution to all our  problems, and the answer to all our  prayers. The title of the film burns in: "RAISING ARIZONA". A buil chord snaps off in a shock cut to:

Tableau of a couple at home. Nathan Arizona is on the  telephone, his stocking feet up on an ottoman. Florence s reading Dr. Spock's Baby and Child Care. The living room is dominated by a large oil portrait of N and Florence, gazing out from the wall over the mantelpie
(into the phone)
Eight hundred leaf tables and no  chairs?! You can't sell leaf tables  and no chairs! Chairs, you got a  dinette set! No chairs, you got dick!  I ask my wife she got more sense!...
From somewhere upstairs we hear an infant start to cry.  Florence stops reading and looks up at the ceiling. Natha is oblivious.

...Miles, all I know is I'm away  from the office to have me some kids  and everything goes straight to heck!  I ain't gonna stand for it! Another title is supered below the first: "SEPTEMBER 17,  1985". The baby stops crying and Florence's attention ret to her book.

...Yeah, and if a frog had wings he  wouldn't bump his ass a-hoppin'! I'm  sick of your excuses, Miles! It is  now... As he throws out his wrist to look at his watch a third t is supered beneath the first two: 8:45 p.m.
...8:45 in the p.m. I'm gonna be  down to the store in exactly twelve  hours to kick me some butt! He starts to replace the receiver but brings it back with afterthought:
...Or my name ain't Nathan Arizona! As he slams the phone into the cradle the titles disappea Another baby starts crying. Florence looks up at the ceil
That sounds like Larry. Close on the crying baby as Hi bounces it, gently but  desperately.

Shhhh! Shh! Nice baby... He starts to lower it back into the crib. The crib is  unpainted with the name of each baby burned Bonanza-style into the headboard: Harry, Barry, Larry, Garry, and Natha Jr. Instead of quieting as he is lowered into the crib, t squalling baby only sets off one of his brothers. Hi hurr lifts him back out. He looks desperately around the room. The room is wallpapered with nursery rhyme characters. There are toys strewn around. There is one adult-sized ea chair in the corner. Hi carries the baby over to the chair, stepping on and  reacting to the squeal of a squeeze-me toy on the way. He sits the baby deep in - the chair and then returns to the crib to deal with the second crying baby. He lifts the baby out of the crib and gently bounces it.  This baby stops crying. Another one in the crib starts bawling. Hi sets the second baby down on the floor and gives it a  rattle to keep it pacified. He reaches for the third baby the crib. Sweat stands out on Hi 's brow. He is desperate chucking the third baby under the chin when we hear a muf
He whirls to look across the darkened room. The first baby has dropped off the easy chair and is  energetically crawling away toward a shadowy corner.
Nathan and Florence are sitting stock-still, staring at t ceiling. After a moment, another baby starts crying.
What're they, playing telephone? They stare at the ceiling.

Loose babies are crawling everywhere. Hi is skittering ac the room in a half-crouch, a baby tucked under one arm,  reaching out with the other as he pursues a crawling baby across the room. He hefts the other baby with his free arm and brings the back to the crib. He turns to look frantically around the room. The other three babies have disappeared. There is perfect quiet. Hi goes over to the closet door, which is ajar, and swing it open. He reaches under a moving pile of clothes on the floor an pulls out a baby. He returns it to the crib and freezes, listening. The sound of a rattle. He drops to the floor to look under the crib.

A baby holding a rattle leers into the camera in the  foreground. Behind him Hi, on his stomach, is reaching in grab at his leg. Hi is pulling the baby out, away from the camera, when wi a plop! a baby drops onto Hi 's back from the crib above. Hi twists one arm back to grope for the baby crawling on of him. He is straightening up, a baby in each arm, when he react in horror to something he sees across the room.
The hindquarters of a diapered baby are just disappearing around the corner of the nursery door into the hallway.
Florence and Nathan are staring at the ceiling. After a b we hear a muffled plop! on the ceiling. A beat later, the bleat of the squeeze-me toy.
...Whyn't you go up and check on  'em? They sound restless.

The floor-level wide-angle shot shows a baby crawling tow the camera in the foreground. Behind him, in the backgrou just rounding the open door from the nursery, yet another baby is making a mad dash for freedom. Hi emerges from the nursery and, stepping around the  background baby, trots toward the baby in the foreground. the time he reaches it the low-angle cropping shows us on his feet and calves.
Perspiring as he tiptoes the last two steps to the baby.
The baby and, beyond it, the stairway down to the main fl We hear footsteps approaching.
He scoops up the baby and hurriedly tiptoes away toward t nursery.

The baby at the nursery door in the foreground; the stair in the background. As Hi reaches the baby we hear footste climbing the stairs. Hi's free arm comes down into frame to scoop the baby up out of frame just as: Florence's head appears, bobbing up as she climbs the sta She approaches the nursery, still clutching the Dr. Spock book.
As Florence enters from the hallway door. We track back into the room, on her, as she approaches th crib. Halfway there she freezes, staring, in shock.

All of the babies have been replaced in the crib but not  lying down: They are seated in a row, staring back at her lined up against the far crib railing, like a small but  distinguished panel on "Meet the Press."

head_text.subj: THROUGH THE WINDSHIELD OF THE CHEVY

text: ED'S POV of Hi approaching the car. He is shrugging and  displaying a pair of manifestly empty hands.
Barely able to fight down her anger. Hissing:
What's the matter?! Hi appears at her - the driver's-window.
Sorry honey, it just didn't work  out. He is reaching to open the door but she slaps his hand aw from the handle.
What d'you mean it didn't work out?!
They started cryin', then they were  all over me... He is trying to open the door, which Ed is holding shut w all her might.
...It was kinda horrifying - Lemme  in, honey.
Course they cried! Babies cry!
I know that now! Come on honey, we  better leave - Ed is rolling up the window and locking the door.
You go right back up there and get  me a toddler! I need a baby, Hi;  they got more'n they can handle! Muffled, through the closed window, and very forlorn:
Aw honey I -
Don't you come back here without a  baby!
Florence is holding one of the babies cradled against her shoulder. She is facing the hallway door; her back is to crib and window. The baby, peeping out over her shoulder, facing the window.
Looking.
Of the window, as Hi's head appears in it.
Looking.
Looking back, he holds a finger to his lips.
Florence starts bouncing it, patting it on the back.
Hi and the window bouncing up and down.
Nathan is leafing through the lingerie ads in the newspap We can hear Florence's returning footsteps. Muttering:
Christian Dior my butt... Florence enters.
...They pay money for that?
Yes dear.
How're the kids?
Fine dear.
Fuckin' kids, I love 'em. We hear the bleat of the squeeze-me toy. Florence and Nat look at the ceiling for a beat, then Nathan clears his th and returns to the newspaper.

Ed sits anxiously waiting in the driver's seat, peering  intently through the windshield. As she catches sight of  something she breaks into a broad smile, unlocks the door and slides over to the passenger seat. Hi is opening the door with one hand, cradling a baby in other.
Which one ya get? As he gets into the driver's seat:
I dunno. Nathan Jr., I think.
Gimme here. He hands her the infant, then hands her the copy of Dr.Sp Baby and Child Care.
Here's the instructions.
Oh, he's beautiful! Hi nods as he pulls away from the curb.
He's awful damn good. I think I got  the best one. Ed is gushing and kissing the baby through the rest of th conversation.
I bet they were all beautiful. All  babies are beautiful!
Yeah. This one's awful damn good  though.
Don't you cuss around him.
He's fine, he is. I think it's Nathan  Jr.
We are doin' the right thing, aren't  we Hi? - I mean, they had more'n  they could handle.
Well now honey we been over this and  over this. There's what's right and  there's what's right, and never the  twain shall meet.
But you don't think his momma'll be  upset? I mean overly?

Well a course she'll be upset, sugar,  but she'll get over it. She's got  four little babies almost as good as  this one. It's like when I was robbin'  convenience stores - Ed suddenly bursts out crying.
I love him so much!
I know you do, honey.
(still sobbing)
I love him so much!
As the lights are thrown on. The room is hung with stream A string of cut-out letters reads "Welcome Home Son!"
Okay, bring him in!
Ed is entering with Nathan Jr.
This is it young Nathan Jr. Just  feast your eyes about, old boy!
Don't be so loud around him, Hi.
(softly)
Damn, I'm sorry honey.
And don't you cuss around him.
Aw, he don't know a cuss word from  shinola.
Well see that he don't.
(jovially)
He's all right, he is. He reaches for the child.

...Come on over here, Nathan Jr.,  I'll show you around. He takes the baby in both hands and holds him out at arm' length, pointing him at the various places of interest. T baby looks goggle-eyed at each one.

...Lookahere, young sportsman. That -  there's the kitchen area where Ma  and Pa chow down. Over there's the  TV, two hours a day maximum, either  educational or football so's you  don't ruin your appreciation of the  finer things. This - here's the divan,  for sociahzin' and relaxin' with the  family unit. Yessir, many's the day  we sat there and said wouldn't it be  nice to have a youngster here to  share our thoughts and feelin's - Impatient with the nonsense:
He's tired, Hi.
Well we'll just sit you right there,  boy... He is propping Nathan Jr. up in the corner of the couch. sits at the other corner and Ed sits in a facing chair.

...Just put those dogs up'n take a  load off. Hi beams at Nathan Jr. Ed smiles at Nathan Jr. Nathan Jr. looks from one to the other, deadpan. They seem to be wai for him to contribute to the conversation. Silence. Suddenly Hi slaps his knee.
What are you kiddin'?! We got a family  here! Ed is getting up.
...He's a scandal, honey! He's a  little outlaw! As she picks up the baby:
He's a good boy.
He ain't too good! You can tell by  that twinkle in his eye!
Don't you think we should put him to  bed?
Hang on, honey... He is frantically reaching for a Polaroid camera.
...Let's us preserve the moment in  pictures!
Just one, okay?... She sits down on the couch with Nathan Jr. as Hi starts  screwing the camera into a tripod.
...I gotta tell ya, I'm a little  scared. Absently, as he sets up the camera:
How come is that, honey?
Well we got a baby, Hi. It's an awful  big responsibility. As he peers through the lens:
Honey, could ya slide over a tad and  raise the nipper up? As she complies:
I mean we never done this before and  I'm kinda nervous.
You're doin' real good, sugar. Hi sits on the couch, holding the camera's cable release. puts his arm around Ed and smiles at the offscreen camera Ed nestles her head against Hi's shoulder.
I love you, Hi.
We're set to pop here, honey.
You're gonna help, aren't ya? Through his teeth as he continues to grin at the offscree camera:
How's that, honey?
Give Nathan Jr. a normal family  background, just quiet evenings at  home together... We begin to hear distant thunder.
You can count on it, honey.
...Everything decent'n normal from  here on out.
Uh-huh. As he squeezes the cable release - FLASH - the image  momentarily freezes on Hi beaming, Nathan Jr. staring, an Ed looking at Hi with a little bit of concern.

The rolling thunder has built to a thunderclap at the cut and the flash of the Polaroid match cuts to lightning thr a momentarily harsh glare on the field. Rain beats down on the bare patch of ground we are lookin at - by now just a patch of mud. Faraway lightning flickers and we hear the rumble of more thunder approaching, then suddenly: THWACK - A head pops up out of the mud. It is Gale, the c we saw in group therapy. He bellows as lightning and thun flash and crack nearby. His head is covered with mud, although the driving rain i already starting to wash it away. We are beginning to track in an arc around Gale's head, w is now struggling, working to get his shoulders and arms out of the mud. The end of the 180-degree arc and a flash lightning reveal, way in the distance, the wire-topped wa of a penitentiary. Still bellowing, as if in some primal rage, Gale has gott his muck-covered arms up out of the earth and is now push down to haul up the rest of his body. It comes with much  effort, and with the loud sucking-popping sounds of the  fiercely clinging mud. Finally he is free. With a great cry, the mud-covered man plunges his right a straight back down into the earth, all the way up to his  shoulder. He gropes intently and then, apparently having  grabbed hold of something underground, he starts pulling. His arm comes slowly back up out of the mud. Clasped in h hand is - a human foot. Bellowing with effort he continues to pull, liberating th foot... leg... torso of his companion, and finally his he As the rain starts to wash the mud off his companion's he we see that it is his friend Evelle. Both are bellowing. Mud sucks and pops. Thunder crashes.

At the cut the ear-splitting thunder drops out to quiet. hear only the muffled patter of rain and the hum of a bar fluorescent. The two bedraggled escaped cons are standing side by side combing their hair in the mirror. The men seem absorbed i their task, using hair jelly from a jar that sits on the  shelf between them to restore their duck's-ass haircuts. Evelle cracks the bathroom door and looks out into the ra
...Okay.
What is it?
Mercury. Looks nice.

The two men are trotting out to a Mercury that sits unten at a gas island, a gas hose on automatic stuck in its tan As Gale starts up the car Evelle yanks the hose out and d it to the ground. Gale is already starting to peel out as Evelle gets in.

Late at night. Hi sits asleep on the sofa at the far end the room, in a pool of lamp light. We hear faint, distant knocking. As we track in toward Hi the knocking becomes louder and more present. As we approach Hi we see that several Polaroids are sprea over his gently rising and falling chest. By the time we tighten on his face the knocking has becom quite loud.
Open up! Hi starts awake with a grunt.
...Open up in air! He looks up, alarmed.
The front door of the trailer. Someone is pounding  insistently.
Open up! It's a police!
He sits up and tenses. He looks around. Ed stands in her nightgown at the mouth of the hallway,  holding Nathan Jr. and squinting at Hi. She hisses:
Hi! What's goin' on?

You know what's goin' on, H.I. It's  just business. Now this can go either  hard or easy- Hi gives Gale a hard push to get past him. Gale staggers  back but recovers and grabs Hi in a bear hug. Hi flips Gale. Gale lands on a coffee table which flips u and crashes back down. Evelle is dancing back out of Hi's reach. As Hi lunges fo him the prostrate Gale grabs his legs. Hi goes down hard. Gale leaps to his feet and - CRASH - bangs his head up ag an overhanging lamp. Both of his hands fly up to massage top of his head. THOOMP - Hi's fist flies into frame to connect with Gale' unguarded stomach. Gale doubles over, clutching at his gu Hi interlaces his fingers to make a club of his two hands With Gale's bowed head a target in front of him, Hi swing his hands up over his head. Hi's knuckles scrape painfully against the plaster of the too - low ceiling. Skin is flayed, plaster crumbles. Hi grabs at his knuckles in pain. Gale lunges with a mid- body tackle that sends Hi crashing into the wall. Gale, still on top of him, reaches back to throw a punch. The reach-back sends his elbow crashing through a window doesn't stop the punch. It connects with Hi's jaw. Gale throws another quick punch, all his weight behind it Hi's head bobs sideways just in time and Gale's fist goes through the wall. It is momentarily stuck there. Hi uses the opportunity to grab Gale's one free arm with  both of his. He is twisting it to make Gale, roaring with pain, twist around and present his back to him. Hi climbs aboard, grabbing Gale's face. Gale, still roaring, is pulling his fist out of the hole. grabs a lath exposed by the hole and pulls; it tears out the wall and snaps free, giving him a length of about two feet. Gale is rampaging around like a grizzly bear hemmed in a small space. Hi is hanging on for dear life, his own feet flailing this way and that, knocking over lamps and wall  fixtures as Gale bends and twirls about, trying to shake loose. Gale crashes and bounces off the walls, roaring in pain and fury. Close shots of Gale's face show his features impossibly a grotesquely contorted by Hi's hand, squeezing, gripping a clutching at it. Evelle is dancing around with the baby, dodging crashing  furniture and flailing body parts.
At the cut Gale's roaring drops out. We hear the chirping birds and the laughter of children playing in the  neighborhood. It is a sunny day.
Gale still roars. With a last mighty effort, he finally s Hi off his body. Hi crashes against a wall and through it to land in the:

Amid a shower of plaster dust and lath. Hi has landed,  groggily, against the toilet. Evelle enters now with his hands free, apparently having the baby down somewhere. He yanks the cord off the bathroom blinds.

Hi is seated in a straight-back chair, still violently  struggling but Gale's arms are wrapped around him from be Evelle is just finishing tying off his wrists behind the  chair. No one talks; there is nothing left to say. Finished, Gale goes to the door and Evelle goes to the  bedroom. He emerges with the baby and precedes Gale out t door, Gale slamming it behind him. Hi starts bucking and struggling, weeping tears of rage a frustration. He succeeds only in tipping forward, face do into the carpet, the strapped-on chair pressing down on t of him. His profile is pressed into the carpet. Offscreen we hear the door of the trailer opening.
At carpet level. Gale's shoes enter his field of vision.  They stride over to a mess of debris in the corner of the living room.
As Gale paws through the wreckage to expose the copy of D Spock's Baby and Child Care. He grabs the book.
The feet walk away and leave his field of vision.
As we hear the door slam shut with horrible finality. Hi's mouth stretches wide. He ROARS with grief and  frustration.

Moving down the road toward an oncoming car. As the oncom car gets closer we can see Gale and Evelle in its front s As the car passes we pan with it, to reveal that we have  been shooting from the inside of another car, and we hold the profile of its driver: Ed. She has just watched the o car shoot past.
...Good.

As Ed sits heavily into frame, apparently in shock, her f profile to the camera as she stares straight ahead into s Her foreground hand absently holds a length of cord. Beyond her in the middle background Hi is rummaging in th debris. He stands up, cropped from the chest down and sta loading bullets into the chamber of Ed's .38 police speci
(frantically)

I know you're worried honey but  believe me, there ain't a thing to  worry about. We're gonna get him  back, there just ain't no question  about that... He snaps the chamber shut and leaves frame, still talking
...We'll get him back, that's just  all there is to it. And you wanna  know another thing? He is walking back into frame holding another handgun now addition to the .38, this one an automatic.

...I'm gonna be a better person from  here on out. And that's final, I  mean that's absolutely the way it's  gonna be, that's official. You were  right and I was wrong... He snaps a clip into the automatic.
...A blind man could tell you that.  Now they ain't gonna hurt him, they're  just in it for the score... Hi is leaving frame again, continuing to talk as we hear rummaging offscreen.

...But I ain't like that no more,  I'm a changed man. You were right  and I was wrong. We got a family  here and I'm gonna start acting  responsibly... Hi enters frame with the two handguns stuck in his belt,  holding his pump-action shotgun.
...So let's go honey... He primes the shotgun: WHOOSH-CLACK.
...Let's go get Nathan Jr.
From the front bumper of an automobile. Beautiful desert  stretches to the horizon. The road rushes under the camer
Gale drives, gazing out at the road. Evelle holds Nathan  Jr., occasionally bouncing him. Contemplatively:
I luuuuv to drive.
You said somethin' there, partner.
...Yessir, I figure with the ransom  and this bank, you'n I'll be sittin'  in the fabled catbird seat. Evelle is looking down at the baby, shifting him in his l
Uh, Gale... Junior had a, uh,  accident.
What's that, pardner?
He had a little accident. Gale looks over.
Wuddya mean, he looks okay.
No, ya see... Movin' though we are,  he just had hisself a rest stop.
Well it's perfectly natural.
(very excited)
Hey Gale!
What now? Evelle, beaming, looks up from the baby to Gale.
...He smiled at me!

A huge rumbling rippling red ball that fills the frame. As we hear his footfalls on concrete steps, Smalls rises  into frame, apparently climbing a stoop. The sun behind h throws him into silhouette; the extreme telephoto flatten him against the sun. Heat waves ripple between us and him making his figure slightly waver. The rumble builds, louder and louder, until it is snapped off by a-

CLICK. The front door handle clicks open and Smalls stand in the doorway. The abandoned trailer is perfectly quiet. The room is a complete shambles from the fight. Sunlight  filters in between the slats of the venetian blinds. Smok from Lenny Smalls' cheroot ripples up through the light. After only a momentary pause at the door to take in the s Smalls goes directly to a specific spot in the debris and nudges some of it aside with his toe, exposing a piece of paper. He bends down to pick it up but suddenly freezes, with a  soft grunt of surprise.
At knee-height on the wall in front of him, "FART" is scr in crayon.
As he stands up with the piece of paper.
It is Gale's picture of the Farmers and Mechanics Bank.
Close on a carton of diapers being set down on the check- counter.
Know how you put these thangs on?

Evelle and the Cashier, a late-middle-aged man (perhaps t proprietor of this small mom-and-pop store) face each oth across the check-out counter. Evelle has various baby  purchases - the diapers, baby food, etc. - piled on the  counter. The Cashier is ringing them up. Through the open door beyond them we can see a strip of t parking lot.
Welp. Around the butt, then up over  the groin area-

I know where they go, old timer. I  mean do I need pins or fasteners? We see Gale trotting past through the visible part of the parking lot, cooing "Weeeeee!" as he holds Nathan Jr. Up  over his head.
Well no, they got those tape-ettes  already on there, it's self-contained  and fairly explanatory.
Uh-huh... He takes a plastic-covered squirt gun off a display rack drops it on the counter. He is looking around at the othe impulse purchases displayed by the register; he unhooks a bag of balloons.
...These blow up into funny shapes  at all? Gale is trotting by in the opposite direction: "Weeeeee!"
Well no. Unless round is funny. Evelle is pulling a gun out of his belt.
All right, I'll take these too. Now  you lie down back there-
Yessir!

And don't you move till you've counted  up to eight hundred and twenty-five  and then backwards down to zero.  I'll be back to check - see y'ain't  cheatin'. The Cashier is already down on the floor, out of frame.
You the diaper burglar? As he heads for the door with the groceries:
Looks like I'm one of 'em.
As Evelle hurriedly emerges with the two bags. Faintly we can hear the Cashier bellowing: "One one thousand, two on thousand..."
Get the door, will ya? Gale is slipping the baby back into his car seat, which s on the roof of the car. He starts doing up the straps.
He's a real cheerful little critter  once he warms up to ya. Hands free now, Gale reaches for the back door.
Hurry up Gale... Gale has the door open. Evelle starts throwing in the  groceries.
I don't know how high this one can  count.
Gale drives as Evelle sorts through his purchases.
I got him some baby grub... baby  wipes... diapers, disposable... packet  of balloons-
They blow up into funny shapes at  all?
No, just- Gale is looking around, puzzled.
Say, where's Junior?
Wuddya mean, didn't you put him in?!
No, I thought- The two men look at each other.
The two men's heads whip around to look in the back seat.
They look at each other in horror.
Where'd we leave him?! The two men's eyes widen as they remember at the same tim both look up at the roof of the car.
Coming off the accelerator.
Screaming as he watches the foot:
But too late.
Already plunging down on the brake. SQUEEEEEEEAL...

Evelle is screaming at the top of his lungs as the car ro to a stop. He peers through the windshield, still screami but nothing has shot off the roof of the car. He cranes his neck to look up the slant of the windshield toward the roof. This of course gives him no view; still  screaming, he thrusts his body out his open window to loo up at the roof. His scream is muted as his head disappear from view, then comes back full force as he ducks back in frantically shaking his head. With this Gale's last hope disappears and he starts bello also.
Rising from the brake to plunge down on the accelerator.
As it hangs a squealing U-turn and races off at top speed
In the foreground Nathan Jr. sits upright in his car seat in the middle of the road that fronts the convenience sto He is placidly looking at the scenery. Faintly, we hear the Cashier bellowing:
...Seven hunnert ninety-seven one  thousand, seven hunnert ninety-six  one thousand...
In their speeding car, both staring out at the road ahead mouths gaping, emitting ear-splitting screams.
Shot faces the front of the store with some of the street visible outside. The Cashier on the floor is out of frame but we can hear him loud and clear:

...Seven hunnert ninety-one one  thousand, seven hunnert - ah...  bullshit. He rises into frame, back to the camera, just as: We see  Gale and Evelle's car, through the front window, roaring the street. Quick as a shot, the Cashier has dropped back out of frame and resumes bellowing:
Seven hunnert ninety - ought one  thousand! Seven hundred eighty - The car is starting to squeal to a screaming halt.

With Nathan Jr. in the foreground. Gale and Evelle's car  comes to a rocking halt behind - and inches shy of - the  baby. Evelle's door is already open. He bolts from it and runs  over to the baby, blubbering. He picks up the car seat an Nathan Jr. Gale is also getting out of the car.
Promise we ain't never gonna give  him up, Gale! We ain't never gonna  let him go! Gale, choked up, speaks in a low unsteady voice:
We'll never give him up, Evelle.  He's our little Gale Jr. now.
Hi driving. Both are staring wordlessly ahead at the road Hi looks over at Ed, glum but trying to be kind.
...Ed, I realize I can't be much of  a comfort to you. But lemme just say  this... He is nodding to himself.
You'll feel a whole lot better when-
I don't wanna feel better.
Honey-
I don't care about myself anymore. I  don't care about us anymore. I just  want Nathan Junior back safe.
I know that-
If we don't get him back safe, I  don't wanna go on livin'. And even  if we do, I don't wanna go on livin'  with you. This shuts Hi up. After a moment:
...I guess I still love you Hi; I  know I do. I ain't even blaming you.  The whole thing was crazy and the  whole thing was my idea. Hi clears his throat.
Well, factually, I myself bear a  very large-

Lemme finish. Since those jailbirds  took little Nathan I been doin' some  thinking, and I ain't too proud of  myself. Even if Mrs. Arizona had  more'n she could handle, I was a  police officer sworn to uphold the  Constitution of the United States -
Now waitaminute honey, you resigned  before we-
That ain't the point, Hi. We don't  deserve Nathan Jr. Any more'n those  jailbirds do. And if I'm as selfish  and irresponsible as you-
Y'ain't that bad, honey.
If I'm as bad as you, what good're  we to each other. You'n me's just a  fool's paradise.
Baking in the noonday sun.
Sitting in the front seat of their idling car, looking at the bank.
There she is.
Yep. Welp... They look at each other. Gale reaches for his door.
...Let's do her.
Waitaminute. What do we do with Gale  Jr.?
Wuddya mean, he waits here.
Are you crazy?!  He can't wait here  by hisself. Supposin' we get killed  in there - it could be hours before  he's discovered.
As Gale and Evelle bang in through the door. Evelle holds shotgun; Gale holds a shotgun in one hand and Nathan Jr. his car seat in the other.
All right you hayseeds, it's a stick- up! Everbody freeze! Everbody down  on the ground! Everyone freezes, staring at Gale and Evelle. An Old Hays with his hands in the air speaks up:
Well which is it young fella? You  want I should freeze or get down on  the ground? Mean to say, iffen I  freeze, I can't rightly drop. And  iffen I drop, I'm a gonna be in  motion. Ya see -
Promptly:
Yessir.
Everone down on the ground!
Y'all can just forget that part about  freezin'.
That is until they get down there.
Y'all hear that? There is a murmur of acknowledgment from all the people o the ground. Gale is tossing Evelle a sack.
Wanna fill that sack, pardner? We  got - shit! He is looking in shock at the tellers' counter.
...Where'd all the tellers go? There is no one behind the counter. A muffled voice from offscreen:
We're down here, sir.
They're down on the ground like you  commanded, Gale.
I told you not to use m'damn name!  Can't you even try to keep from  forget'n that?! Evelle is momentarily abashed, but then brightens:
Not even yer code name? Gale registers understanding.
Oh yeah... m'code name.
Y'all hear that? There is a murmur of acknowledgment from all the people o the ground.
All right now everone, we're just  about ready to begin the robbery  proper...
The camera is locked down on the roof of the rocketing sq car, looking past its flashing gumballs. The car is approaching the townlet, its siren wailing.

A teller is finishing stuffing the last of two burlap bag Close on her hands, we see her putting in a cash packet t is really only a few bills and a sleeve surrounding and h a small plastic device. The teller hits a button on the device and it starts tick she shoves it into the sack.

All right now everyone, you know how  this works: Y'all stay flattened for  ten full minutes... He is grabbing the two sacks and tosses one to Gale, who  also picks up the baby. As the two are backing toward the door:
...We might come back in five to  check. That's for us to know and y'a  to find out.
Anyone found bipedal in five wears  his ass for a hat. They bolt out the door.
Siren jumps in loud at the cut. It is the same locked-dow shot over the gumballs.
Peeling out from in front of the bank.
Gale is driving; Evelle starts pawing through one of the  sacks.
That old timer threw off my  concentration. Otherwise it would a  gone smoother.

We done okay. Yessir. This ought to  split nicely three ways. A thought registers with Gale and Evelle at the same mome They look at each other. They both twist frantically to l in the back seat. Bellowing:

Goddamnit! Ya never leave a man  behind! KA-POP! With a loud flat crack something detonates in the front seat and the interior of the car is spattered with  bright blue paint. Gale and Evelle, both covered in blue, are screaming in r fear and incomprehension. Blue dollar bills snap and flut around the inside of the car. The car is swerving wildly as Gale drives blind, the insi of the windshield covered with blue paint. He reaches for to wipe clear a patch of windshield.
As the blue paint is smeared away we see Hi and Ed's car  parked broadside in the middle of the road. Hi and Ed are front of it, Hi aiming his scatter gun, Ed a revolver. The guns spit orange flame.

Down the barrel of his shotgun. The car with the blue int is swerving crazily at us, one front tire blown out. Hi lets go with the other barrel. The shot chews up the front grill, shatters one headlight and blows out the other front tire. The hood of the car f open. The car is squealing to a halt and Gale and Evelle pile o still bellowing.

Goddamnit H.I., ain't we got enough  to contend with? Ed is running over to Gale and Evelle's car, throwing ope the back door to look for the baby but coming out only wi Dr. Spock's Baby and Child Care. Evelle is staggering around in shock, looking in disbelie at his own blue body.
Where's the baby? Evelle points this way and that, in a state of confusion.
I think we left him on the roof of  the... he must be back at the... Hi and Ed are climbing into their car.
Let us come with you! Hi and Ed are already peeling out.

...He's our baby too! CLOSE ON NATHAN JR. Sitting placidly in his car seat that sits in the middle the road in front of the bank. We can hear the wail of the police siren still approachin As we hold on Nathan Jr. we hear the distant booming of a shotgun. As we boom up to show the empty street beyond the baby, w hear the crack of return fire and furiously squealing bra The screech culminates in a loud explosion that snaps off the siren wail. The police car is apparently history. From beyond the crest of the road ahead a ball of flame h leapt up with the explosion. As the explosion echoes and  fades we hear the deep rumble of an approaching engine. Lenny Smalls' motorcycle appears over the rise. Framed ag fire and smoke, he is coming directly toward us, and the  baby.
As they top a rise coming from the other direction. We se the baby sitting in the middle of the street, and Lenny f approaching from the background.

The extremely low wide shot, locked down to the speeding  bike, shows us rushing toward the rear of Nathan Jr's car seat. With a clank of chains Lenny's hand drops down into frame palm forward, tensing to scoop up the car seat that we ar almost upon. A tattoo on Lenny's wrist reads "No Prisoners."
Low shot with Nathan Jr. in the foreground. He is scooped up and out of frame as Lenny roars by.
Roaring along. He hooks the car seat over his handlebars.
Lenny is approaching. Under her breath:
What is he?
...D'you see him too? Lenny is sawing a shotgun out of his back holster and lev it at the oncoming car. Lenny is sighting down the gun, swinging it around as he  approaches the car.

head_text.subj: HI AND ED DUCK JUST AS

text: The shotgun spits orange flame and the windshield explode in. Lenny roars by.
The baby on the handlebars in the foreground; the road ru by beyond him. The bike banks into a hard turn.

Shooting through where the windshield used to be, cutting at the end of the skid as the car rocks to a halt. Hi and Ed are raising their heads. Facing forward, they d not see Lenny approaching again through the rear window. He is sawing out his second shotgun. Hi looks around, reaches and pulls Ed down beneath him ju as: KA-BOOM! - The second shotgun roars and the back window s in. As Lenny roars past the back window he casually flips  something in.

head_text.subj: LOOKING DOWN AT HI AND ED

text: Folded over in the front seat. Below them something bounc into and around the leg well - Lenny's grenade.
As the two front doors fly open and Hi and Ed spill out - from the driver's side, heading for the far side of the r and Ed from the passenger side.
As she dives for cover behind a parked car. Beyond her -  KABOOM! - their car explodes and bounces, pouring black s
The explosion flings him to the ground in the middle of t street.

Looking up the street to where Lenny is wheeling his bike a U-turn. He is not finished yet. Hi flat on his back, woozily shaking his head. He weakly raises himself on his elbows to look down the  street.
Looking down the length of his own body. His legs stretch away in a V. Crashing down from a wheelie, Lenny's roaring bike is alm upon him - aiming up the middle of the V.
He rolls. As the bike is roaring by:
Reaches and snags a chain on Lenny's passing boot.
Dragged several yards before the boot shakes him off, lea him on his stomach in the middle of the road. Hi looks up the road.
Lenny is again sluing the bike around.
Smoking as it skids around in the foreground, completing turn. Boom up Lenny's back to reveal Ed stomping straight up th street toward him - unarmed, unafraid.
I want that baby!
He reaches back to pull up his shirt, revealing a gun tuc in his pants in the small of his back. He grabs the gun.
As Ed closes in.
Gimme that baby, you warthog from  hell! Lenny's arms rise into frame. With a roll of his wrists t knives appear in his hands.
On his stomach, sighting down the gun toward Lenny.
Ed stepping into his line of fire, blocking Lenny.
Raising an arm to stab. Ed stoops to scoop the baby from the car seat, revealing: Hi, behind her. He fires.
Drilled by Hi's bullet, drops its knife. The exit wound spurts, not flesh and blood, but a brief j of fire.
Quick as a flash hurling the other knife at Hi.
As the knife stings the gun out of his hand.

head_text.subj: KNIFE ON THE GROUND AT LENNY'S FEET

text: Lenny bends to scoop up the knife he dropped.
As she runs toward the bank, clutching Nathan Jr. to her  chest.
As Ed bursts in. The floor is littered with obedient hays From where he lies prone:
Just lie down on the floor, missie. BANG: The front door bursts open before Lenny's roaring h It sails off a step into the sunken atrium, and lands wit CRASH amidst the hayseeds.
As she runs for the back door and pushes through it.
As he slaloms through the wildly scattering hayseeds.
As Lenny bursts out. With a whipcrack effect he looks left, then right. He jer the bike right, to where an alleyway flanks the side of t bank.
Ed is running up the alley toward the front of the bank a Lenny enters. He roars after her.
Roaring down the alley.
As the bike approaches behind her.
Closing on Ed as she reaches the mouth of the alley. A pl swings into frame, straight at the camera.
Matching action as Hi finishes swinging the plank into Le face. Lenny hits the ground hard as his bike spins out from und him.
Riderless, twisting crazily into the street where it  collapses.
Lenny is rising to his feet beyond them as Hi nods  encouragement to Ed.

Run along now, honey. Lenny is reaching back to throw his knife. Hi, unaware, is turning to face him, presenting the plank the knife is thrown. It thunks into the plank, piercing it through. Hi backs up, swinging the knife - studded plank to make L keep his distance.
As he reaches up to unhook a chain from a ring on his ves shoulder.
As the free chain drops down into his palm.
Swinging the chain - WHOOSH WHOOSH - at the backpedaling
As the chain snakes around it and rips it out of Hi's han
Grabbing Hi by the shirtfront.
Swings down and brass knuckles appear on it.
As Lenny's fist swings into frame to club him forehand, t backhand. An uppercut from his heels sends Hi sprawling back.
As Hi lands against it, banging his head. He sinks to the ground. Lenny is casually walking toward him, lighting a cheroot. flops over onto his stomach and starts wriggling under th car.

Hi's face in the foreground as he desperately seeks escap Behind him we can see Lenny casually reaching down and  grabbing an ankle. The shot is framed identically to the shot in the Arizona nursery where Hi pulled a baby from under the crib. Lenny pulls. Hi is dragged away from the camera and out f under the car.
Struggling to stand up. Lenny wraps his arms around him and applies a tremendous  bear hug.
Crushed against Lenny. His hands paw futilely at Lenny's  chest.
Lenny finally flings Hi away.
Landing in the dust, all the fight beaten out of him.
Tired of the fight: He saws out both shotguns
On the guns as Lenny's thumbs draw them back. He raises t guns to fire.
The end of the road. He wearily lifts a hand, defensively extending it in fron of him - then stops, staring at:
A hand grenade pin hangs, glinting, from one of his finge Pawing at Lenny's chest he must have hooked his finger th its ring.
Reacting.
Reacting to Hi reacting. He looks down.
On the bandoliers across his chest, silver pins glint in the grenades - except one. Its squeeze-lever juts at a ri angle from the grenade.
Hi's jaw drops.
The lit cheroot hits the ground between his boots.
Scrambling to his feet.
Trying to drop the shotguns to free his hands. In his pan his fingers tangle in the trigger guards.
Starting to run.
Finally freeing his hands.
Diving behind the parked car.
His hands fly in to wrap around the grenade - too late -  bright light:
Blows sky-high. There is a roar as if the earth were crac open and flame as if hell were slipping out. We pan the fire to the sky.
A white aluminum ladder rises up into the blackness, clan softly. The top of the ladder arcs toward the camera.
To the interior of the Arizona second-story nursery as th ladder comes to rest against the window frame. It is late at night; the nursery is dark and empty.

Of the unpainted crib with the burned-in names: Harry, Ba Larry, Garry, and Nathan Jr. As we pull back from the headboard Ed's arms are gently  depositing the sleeping Nathan Jr. into the crib. Hi puts the singed copy of Dr. Spock's Baby and Child Care next t the baby.
Hi and Ed looking sadly down at the baby. The silence is broken by the bleat of a squeeze-me toy as the lights are snapped on. Hi and Ed turn, startled.
Nathan stands in his jammies, hair disheveled, holding a and squinting against the light. Keeping the gun trained on Hi and Ed, he slowly raises a  pair of eyeglasses to his nose.
The hell is goin' on? He advances cautiously into the nursery, gesturing with h gun.

...Get away from there. Hi and Ed back away from the crib. Nathan peers in and studies the baby for a moment. He lays the gun down, tenderly picks up the baby and hold him to his chest. A tear forms at the corner of his eye. Hi and Ed are quietly moving back towards the ladder.
(sharply)
Waitaminute... Hi and Ed Stop.
...I ain't through with you. What're  you doin' creepin' around here in  the dark? You in with Smalls?
...Scuse me? As he bounces the baby, studying Hi and Ed:
Leonard Smalls, big fella rides a  Harley, dresses like a rock star?
No sir, that's who we saved him from.  It's a long story.
Suppose you tell it.
Well, sir, in a re-ward situation,  they usually say no questions asked.
Do they. Hi shrugs. Nathan turns to put the baby back in the crib.
...All right, boy, I guess you got a  re-ward coming. Twenty thousand  dollars... He turns around with a thought:
...Or, if you need home furnishings,  I can give you a fine of credit at  any of my stores. Fact, that's the  way I'd rather handle it, for tax  reasons...
Well- Nathan throws his hands up in the air.
But it's up to you.
Tell you the truth, I think we'd  prefer the ca-
We don't want no reward. Hi does a small take, surprised at this much integrity.
...We didn't bring him back for money.
Well, we could work it that way too.
Could I just look at him a little  bit more? She stands looking into the crib. Hi steps up next to her and puts an arm around her shoulder.
Be my guest, young lady... but would  you mind tellin' me exactly how you- Ed starts crying softly as she gazes into the crib. Hi mu something to comfort her. Nathan is studying the two of them.
...You took him, didn't you? Wasn't  that biker a'tal. Hi turns to face him. He speaks in a rush.
I took him, sir, my wife had nothin'  to do with it. I crept in yon window  and-
(still crying)
We both did it. We didn't wanna hurt  him any; I just wanted to be a mama.
It wasn't for money or nothin'. We  just figured you had more'n you could  handle, babywise. But I'm the one  committed the actual crime sir, if  you need to call the authorities-
Shutup boy, no one's callin' the  authorities if there's no harm done.
Thank you sir.
Thank you sir.
Aw bullshit. Just tell me - just  tell me why you did it.
We can't have our own. Nathan looks at her. Finally he nods and sighs.

...Well lookit. If you can't have  kids you gotta just keep tryin' and  hope medical science catches up with  you. Like Florence'n me - it caught  up with a vengeance. And hell, even  if it never does, you still got each  other.
Sir, those're kind words. But I think  the wife and me are splittin' up... He indicates Ed with a nod of the head.
...Her point of view is we're both  kinda selfish and unrealistic, so we  ain't too good for each other.

Well ma'am, I don't know much but I  do know human bein's. You brought  back my boy so you must have your  good points too. I'd sure hate to  think of Florence leavin' me - I do  love her so... He clears his throat and turns to the door. His tone is h again:
...You can go out the way you came  in... He snaps off the lights.
...And before you go off and do  another foolish thing, like busting  up, I suggest you sleep on it... He has disappeared into the hall. We hear his voice reced
...at least one night.
Looking straight down at Hi, asleep in the trailer bedroo We start to crane down.
That night I had a dream...

A beautiful dusk landscape. We are floating in over the f abutting the prison, that Gale and Evelle popped out of. In the middle background of the extreme long shot two men are walking across the field.
...I dreamt I was as light as the  ether, a floating spirit visiting  things to come...
Craning down toward Hi.
The shades and shadows of the people  in my life wrastled their way into  my slumber.
Still floating forward but now much closer to the two wal men. We see that they are Gale and Evelle. Both are still dyed blue. They are approaching the hole in the ground.
I dreamt that Gale and Evelle had  decided to return to prison... Evelle is starting to climb into the hole.
...Probably that's just as well. I  don't mean to sound superior, and  they're a swell couple guys, but... Evelle has disappeared and Gale starts climbing in.
...maybe they weren't ready yet to  come out into the world.

head_text.subj: FLOATING UP THE WALK OF THE ARIZONA HONE

text: The front door has a holly wreath on it.
And then I dreamed on, into the  future, to a Christmas morn in the  Arizona home...
Five three-year-olds in their pajamas are opening present around a tree as Nathan and Florence look on.

...where Nathan Jr. was opening a  present from a kindly couple who  preferred to remain unknown. We have been isolating in on one of the children peeling wrappings off a package marked to Nathan Jr. Inside is a  shiny red plastic football.

head_text.subj: FLOATING IN TOWARD A STATION WAGON

text: Pulled over on the state highway in the middle of the des a police motorcycle parked behind it. Glen is leaning out the driver's window of the car talking to the state troop who stands facing him.

I saw Glen, a few years later, still  havin' no luck gettin' the cops to  listen to his wild tales about me'n  Ed... Glen is grinning and talking with his hands cupped in fro of him, as when he told Hi about the Pollack who almost  stepped in the pile of shit. The trooper, in crash helmet and dark sunglasses, is list tight-lipped and stone-faced as Glen finishes his story a slaps his knee.
...Maybe he threw in one Pollack  joke too many... The trooper is clicking open his ballpoint pen and reachi his citation book from his breast pocket. The name tag on the pocket says "SGT. KOWALSKI."
...I don't know.
It sits on a tee in the middle of a football field.
And still I dreamed on... A cleated foot boots the football out of frame.
...further into the future than I'd  ever dreamed before.
Looking up, arms out at his sides, waiting to receive the kicked ball.
...Watching Nathan Jr.'s progress  from afar... He catches the ball and starts running.
...Taking pride in his accomplishments  as if he were our own... He is skillfully eluding and stiff-arming tacklers.
...Wondering if he ever thought of  us. He reaches the end zone and triumphantly spikes the footb He whips off his helmet and we track in on the face of th rosy-cheeked high-school bruiser.
...and hoping that maybe we'd  broadened his horizons a little,  even if he couldn't remember just  how they'd got broadened.
Still craning down, now very close to the sleeping Hi.
But still I hadn't dreamt nothin'  about me'n Ed. Until the end...

The man and woman are sitting on a sofa in the foreground with their backs to the camera. They are in the living ro of Hi and Ed's trailer, which is suffused with a warm gol light. As they face the trailer's front door, all we see of the  couple is the backs of their heads. They both have white  hair, the woman's pulled into a bun. The old man wears a  cardigan, the woman a shawl.

...And this was cloudier 'cause it  was years, years away. The front door bursts open. Two young couples are enterin as their kids - about a dozen of them - stream in around  them. The old couple on the couch raise their arms to embrace t visitors. The children boil onto the couch.

...But I saw an old couple bein'  visited by their children - and all  their grandchildren too. And the old  couple wasn't screwed up, and neither  were their kids or their grandkids.  And I don't know, you tell me. This  whole dream, was it wishful thinking?   Was I just fleein' reality, like I  know I'm liable to do?

head_text.subj: FLOATING IN TOWARD A LONG DINING TABLE

text: In the trailer. The table is all laid out with a Thanksgi dinner, a huge turkey sitting at the far end. Cut-out letters at the other end of the room say: "WELCOM
The grandchildren are running into frame and taking their seats at the table, accompanied by their parents.
...But me'n Ed, we can be good too... The elderly couple enter from either side of the camera a stand in the foreground, backs to us, facing the table.

...And it seemed real. It seemed  like us. And it seemed like well...  our home... If not Arizona, then a  land, not too far away, where all  parents are strong and wise and  capable, and all children are happy  and beloved... I dunno, maybe it was  Utah. The elderly man drapes an arm around his wife's shoulder draws her close. She rests her head against his shoulder, and we:
